import pandas as pd
nomes = ["A1","A2","A3","A4","A5","A6","A7","A8","A9","A10","A11","A12","A13","A14","A15","A16"]
df = pd.read_csv("/kaggle/input/creditscreening/credit.data", sep = ",", names = nomes, na_values = '?')
df.head()
source.af313ff0:
lista = ['A1','A4','A5','A6','A7','A9','A10','A12','A13']
for i in lista:
    df[i] = df[i].astype(str)
    df[i] = df[i].astype('category')
source.5d9e4443:
X = dic.data
y = dic.target

from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split 
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X,y, test_size=0.2)
X_train.shape
source.89556004:
from sklearn.neighbors import KNeighborsClassifier
knn = KNeighborsClassifier(n_neighbors=3)
modelo = knn.fit(X_train,y_train)
y_pred = modelo.predict(X_test)
y_score = modelo.score(X_test,y_test)
y_score
source.a8bae6d9:
from sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeClassifier, export_graphviz
dtc = DecisionTreeClassifier()
modelo = dtc.fit(X_train,y_train)
y_train = modelo.predict(X_test)
#guarde o resultado da predição em uma nova coluna "predictAD"
import graphviz as gpz
dot_data = export_graphviz(dtc)
graph = gpz.Source(dot_data)
graph
source.43c6d79b:
*  Colunas Categóricas: A1, A4, A5, A6, A7, A9, A10, A12, A13
*  Colunas Categóricas com valores faltantes : A1, A4, A5, A6, A7 preencher com a moda (valor que mais aparece na coluna)
*  Colunas com valores contínuos: A2, A3, A8, A11, A14, A15
*  Colunas com valores contínuos com valores faltantes:  A2 e A14 preencher com média

source.1ec7cc17:
1. Title: Credit Approval
2. Sources: 
    (confidential)
    Submitted by quinlan@cs.su.oz.au
3.  Past Usage:
    See Quinlan,
    * "Simplifying decision trees", Int J Man-Machine Studies 27, Dec 1987, pp. 221-234.
    * "C4.5: Programs for Machine Learning", Morgan Kaufmann, Oct 1992
4.  Relevant Information:
    This file concerns credit card applications.  All attribute names
    and values have been changed to meaningless symbols to protect
    confidentiality of the data.
    This dataset is interesting because there is a good mix of
    attributes -- continuous, nominal with small numbers of
    values, and nominal with larger numbers of values.  There
    are also a few missing values.
5.  Number of Instances: 690
6.  Number of Attributes: 15 + class attribute
7.  Attribute Information:
    A1:	b, a.
    A2:	continuous.
    A3:	continuous.
    A4:	u, y, l, t.
    A5:	g, p, gg.
    A6:	c, d, cc, i, j, k, m, r, q, w, x, e, aa, ff.
    A7:	v, h, bb, j, n, z, dd, ff, o.
    A8:	continuous.
    A9:	t, f.
    A10:	t, f.
    A11:	continuous.
    A12:	t, f.
    A13:	g, p, s.
    A14:	continuous.
    A15:	continuous.
    A16: +,-         (class attribute)
8.  Missing Attribute Values:
    37 cases (5%) have one or more missing values.  The missing
    values from particular attributes are:
    A1:  12 ; A2:  12; A4:   6;  A5:   6; A6:   9;   A7:   9;    A14: 13
9.  Class Distribution
      +: 307 (44.5%)    -: 383 (55.5%)
source.6f489f81:
4 - Preencha os campos das colunas com valores categóricos com a moda dos valores da coluna, para isso use a função fillna( ) e moda( )
    * defina um vetor com as colunas a serem alteradas
    * use um laço para varrer o vetor   (for n in colunas: df.fillna...)
